**Iceland Index**. A plot of raw species counts from equal-area hexagons approximately the size of Iceland. This plot excludes international waters, but includes countries EEZ areas. We see here that while **Iceland** has <span style="color:#749DC7"><b>>5K species</b></span> other areas within Amazonia, Eastern Europe, and Africa have suspiciously fewer, **indicating a likely data gap**.

## What are the GBIF regions? 

```{R,echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE,echo=FALSE, results="hide"}
plot_name = "gbif_region_map"
plot_folder = "gbif region map"
```

![](`r path_to_plots`/`r plot_name`.svg)

<div style="text-align:right;"><sub>
[jpg](`r github_path`/gbif region map/jpg/`r plot_name`.jpg) | 
[pdf](`r github_path`/gbif region map/pdf/`r plot_name`.pdf) | 
[svg](`r github_path`/gbif region map/svg/`r plot_name`.svg) | 
[code](https://github.com/jhnwllr/gbif_regional_statistics)
</div>

The [GBIF Network](https://www.gbif.org/the-gbif-network) is divided into regions. These regions are derived from the [IPBES](https://ipbes.net/) regional assessments, shown on this [map](https://www.nature.com/articles/sdata20167/figures/1). This post will cover countries/areas with some political status and not on other [GBIF Affiliates]( https://www.gbif.org/the-gbif-network/gbif-affiliates) and Antarctica. 


## <span style="color:#509E2F"><b>Occurrence</b></span> and <span style="color:#F1AD16"><b>Species</b></span> counts

```{R,echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE,echo=FALSE, results="hide"}
plot_name = "gbif_regions_occ_count"
plot_folder = "comparison barchart"
```

![](`r path_to_plots`/`r plot_name`.svg)

<div style="text-align:right;"><sub>
[jpg](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/jpg/`r plot_name`.jpg) | 
[pdf](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/pdf/`r plot_name`.pdf) | 
[svg](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/svg/`r plot_name`.svg) | 
[code](https://github.com/jhnwllr/gbif_regional_statistics)
</div>

**Europe & Central Asia** and **North America** have by far the most occurrences about/published in their regions. A large part of these records are from bird observations, which is reflected in the species-count graph below.  


```{R,echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE,echo=FALSE, results="hide"}
plot_name = "gbif_regions_num_species"
plot_folder = "comparison barchart"
```

![](`r path_to_plots`/`r plot_name`.svg)

<div style="text-align:right;"><sub>
[jpg](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/jpg/`r plot_name`.jpg) | 
[pdf](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/pdf/`r plot_name`.pdf) | 
[svg](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/svg/`r plot_name`.svg) | 
[code](https://github.com/jhnwllr/gbif_regional_statistics)
</div>

**Latin America & The Caribbean** have the most species about their region, which makes sense from a [species-richness perspective](https://explorer.naturemap.earth/map). **Europe & Central Asia** and **North America** publish the most species, which could occur in any region or in international waters.   

## <span style="color:#FF9326"><b>Birds</b></span> dominate occurrence totals

```{R,echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE,echo=FALSE, results="hide"}
plot_name = "facet_stacked_num_of_occ_Global_nobirds_FALSE"
plot_folder = "country stacked barplots facet"
```

![](`r path_to_plots`/`r plot_name`.svg)

<div style="text-align:right;"><sub>
[jpg](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/jpg/`r plot_name`.jpg) | 
[pdf](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/pdf/`r plot_name`.pdf) | 
[svg](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/svg/`r plot_name`.svg) | 
[code](https://github.com/jhnwllr/gbif_regional_statistics)
</div>

<span style="color:#FF9326"><b>Birds</b></span>, of course, dominate occurrence records in almost all countries and regions, particularly in **North America**. I plot the same graph below excluding birds and countries with less than 1 million total occurrences. 

```{R,echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE,echo=FALSE, results="hide"}
plot_name = "facet_stacked_num_of_occ_Global_nobirds_TRUE"
plot_folder = "country stacked barplots facet"
```

![](`r path_to_plots`/`r plot_name`.svg)

<div style="text-align:right;"><sub>
[jpg](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/jpg/`r plot_name`.jpg) | 
[pdf](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/pdf/`r plot_name`.pdf) | 
[svg](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/svg/`r plot_name`.svg) | 
[code](https://github.com/jhnwllr/gbif_regional_statistics)
</div>

<span style="color:#FF0040"><b>A large red bar</b></span> indicates that the country has many occurrences about the country that are not in the top most popular groups (<span style="color:#FF9326"><b>Birds</b></span>, <span style="color:#509E2F"><b>Plants</b></span>, <span style="color:#40BFFF"><b>Insects</b></span>, <span style="color:#175CA1"><b>Mammals</b></span>, <span style="color:#FFCCCC"><b>Molluscs</b></span>, <span style="color:#FDAF02"><b>Fungi</b></span>). <span style="color:#FF0040"><b>Other</b></span> records are usually fish, amphibians, or reptiles. These graphs largely show a publishing bias towards the familar, which is not surprising. One can search for a country (e.g. [The United States](https://www.gbif.org/occurrence/taxonomy?country=US)) on the GBIF web interface and get a more detailed view of that country's taxanomic breakdown.

## Species gains over time

```{R,echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE,echo=FALSE, results="hide"}
plot_name = "timeseries_num_species"
plot_folder = "time series"
```

![](`r path_to_plots`/`r plot_name`.svg)

<div style="text-align:right;"><sub>
[jpg](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/jpg/`r plot_name`.jpg) | 
[pdf](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/pdf/`r plot_name`.pdf) | 
[svg](`r github_path`/`r plot_folder`/svg/`r plot_name`.svg) | 
[code](https://github.com/jhnwllr/gbif_regional_statistics)
</div>

GBIF regions gain around **25-50K new species every two years**. In 2022-2024 **Africa** will have the same number of species as **North America** had on GBIF in 2016-2018.
